review.title: Using Global Constraints and Reranking to Improve Cognates Detection
review.abstract: Global constraints and reranking have not been used in cognates detection research to date. We propose methods for using global constraints by performing rescoring of the score matrices produced by state of the art cognates detection systems. Using global constraints to perform rescoring is complementary to state of the art methods for performing cognates detection and results in significant performance improvements beyond current state of the art performance on publicly available datasets with different language pairs and various conditions such as different levels of baseline state of the art performance and different data size conditions, including with more realistic large data size conditions than have been evaluated with in the past.

sections.heading: 2 Algorithm
sections.text: While our focus in this paper is on the use of global constraints to improve like-minded detection, we believe that our method is generally useful. Therefore, we abstract some of the specifics of like-minded detection and present our algorithm more generally in this section, hoping that in the future it can be used for other applications in addition to detecting like-minded people. None of our abstractions detract from our understanding of the applicability of our method to detecting like-minded people and the fact that the method can in no way detract from the benefit we show it has in improving like-minded people. A common attitude is where you get a lot of X = {x1, x2,... xn} and a lot of Y = {y1, y2, yn} where the task is to extract (x, y) pairs that are related.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: Our goal is to test whether the use of the global structural algorithms we have described in Section 2 can significantly increase performance for cognate detection. To test this hypothesis, our first step is to implement a system that uses the latest research results to generate the initial score matrices, as a current state-of-the-art system would currently do for this task. To this end, we implemented a basic state-of-the-art system that uses the information sources that have proven helpful for this task, such as phonetic information, word context information, temporal context information, word frequency information, and word burstiness information (Kondrak, 2001; Mann and Yarowsky, 2001; Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002; Klementiev and Roth, 2006; Irvine and Callison-Burch, 2013). Consistent with past work (we reviewed the Irvine and Callison performance on the Spanish information system in 2013, we were able to use the different weights).

sections.heading: 3.1 Lemmatization
sections.text: We used morphological analyzers to transform the words in text corpora into lemmas. In English we used the NLTK WordNetLemmatizer (Bird et al., 2009), in French, German and Spanish we used the TreeTagger (Schmid, 1994).

sections.heading: 3.2 Word Context Information
sections.text: We used the Google-N-gram corpus (Michel et al., 2010). For English we used the English Google-5-gram corpus of 2012, for French the French Google-5-gram corpus of 2012, for German the German Google-5-gram corpus of 2012 and for Spanish the Spanish Google-5-gram corpus of 2012. From these corpus we calculate linguistic context similarity values according to the method of Rapp (Rapp, 1995, 1999). The intuition behind this method is that cognates are more likely to occur in correlated context windows and this statistic from large amounts of data captures this correlation.

sections.heading: 3.3 Frequency Information
sections.text: The intuition is that large amounts of data should have similar relative frequencies. We calculate our relative frequencies by using the same corpora mentioned in the previous section.

sections.heading: 3.4 Temporal Information

sections.heading: 3.5 Word Burstiness
sections.text: The intuition is that like-minded people will have similar bursting dimensions (Church and Gale, 1995). We used the same corpora for verbal bursting as for temporal corpora.

sections.heading: 3.6 Phonetic Information
sections.text: The intuition is that like-minded people have correspondences in their pronunciation. To do this, we calculate a measurement based on the Normalized Processing Distance (NED).

sections.text: We combine the information sources by using a linear support vector machine to learn the weights for each of the information sources from a small group of like-minded people. sections.heading: 4 Discussion
sections.text: We believe that this work opens up new avenues for further exploration, some of which include: • Exploring the benefits of applying and extending the method to other applications, such as information extraction applications, many of which have similar global limitations to the recognition of equivalents; • Exploring the use of other forms of global structures, including trends that are not necessarily subject to severe limitations; • Developing more theory to better understand some nuances of the use of global structures when they are applicable, and establishing links with other areas of machine learning, such as semi-supervised learning, active learning, etc.; and • Exploring how to make a machine learn that global structures exist and learn what form of global structures exists.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: Cognate recognition is an interesting and challenging task. Previous work has produced a matrix of scores for all word pairs based on various helpful information sources such as phonetics, word context information, temporal context information, word frequency information, and word burstiness information. However, when mapping a score to a word pair, the current state of the art does not take into account scores associated with other word pairs. We proposed a matrix correction method that would produce current state-of-the-art methods by taking into account the scores of other word pairs. The methods presented in this paper complement existing state-of-the-art methods that are easy to implement, compress efficiently, and practically effective in improving performance by large amounts. Experimental results show that the new methods significantly improve the state of the art by conducting cognate recognition experiments that are performed on freely available and publicly available data pairs with different language pairings, including different cognate sizes.
